io.github.ddimitrov.nuggets

Class TextTable

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.ddimitrov.nuggets.TextTable

  • public class TextTable
extends Object

    Entry Point Formats data as text-table, suitable for logging and printing. The recommended way is to use a builder-based DSL (though you may use the classes directly to achieve advanced scenarios). All following examples focus on the DSL:

    
 String table = TextTable.withColumns("key", "value", "notes")
                         .withData()
                         .row("OP", "Austin Powers", "International Man of Mystery")
                         .row("NP", "Nigel Powers", "NP complete")
                         .buildTable()
                         .format(10, new StringBuilder())
                         .toString();

    Which will be rendered as:

    
 +-----+---------------+------------------------------+
 | key | value         | notes                        |
 +-----+---------------+------------------------------+
 | OP  | Austin Powers | International Man of Mystery |
 | NP  | Nigel Powers  | NP complete                  |
 +-----+---------------+------------------------------+
    We may as well specify different visual style like this: 
    
 presetBox(Box.UNICODE_THIN); // will draw the table using nice thin box characters.

    Which will change the rendering to a nice box using unicode's pseudo-graphic characters. (Blame Java's encoding handling for not being able to include it in the Javadoc easily.)

    Typically, we would want to define the table layout once and use it to format multiple data sets:

    
 TextTable.LayoutBuilder layout = TextTable.withColumns("key", "value", "notes");

 layout.withData()
       .row("OP", "Austin Powers", "International Man of Mystery")
       .row("NP", "Nigel Powers", "NP complete")
       .buildTable()
       .format(10, System.err);

 layout.withData()
       .row("foo", "Fubar", "beyond all repair")
       .row("baz", "Bazqux", "")
       .buildTable()
       .format(10, System.err);

    Or we may keep the table object around and format it to different outputs:

    
 TextTable table = TextTable.withColumns("key", "value")
                            .column("notes") // columns can be specified one-by-one
                            .withData()
                            .rows( // add rows in bulk
                              new String[] { "OP", "Austin Powers", "International Man of Mystery" },
                              new String[] { "NP", "Nigel Powers", "NP complete" },
                            )
                            .row()
                            .buildTable();

 table.format(0, System.err);
 table.format(10, System.out);
 StringBuilder renderedTable = table.format(10, new StringBuilder());

    By default each column is mandatory, left-aligned and rendered as string with 1 space padding. We can tweak all these per column with DSL like this:

    
 TextTable.LayoutBuilder layout = TextTable
      .withColumns()
      .column("key"  , c -> c.alignment=1) // right-aligned
      .column("value", c -> c.padding = 0) // remove padding
      .column("notes", c -> {
            c.defaultValue="n/a";
            c.formatter = val -> val.toString().toLowerCase(); // custom formatter
       });

    If a value is an instance of Supplier or Callable (or id the value is null and the default value is instance of these interfaces), the functional interface will be called and the result will be rendered.

    
 TextTable.LayoutBuilder layout = TextTable
      .withColumns()
      .column("key"  , c -> c.alignment=1) // right-aligned
      .column("value", c -> c.padding = 0) // remove padding
      .column("notes", c -> {
            c.defaultValue="n/a;
            c.formatter = val -> val.toString().toLowerCase(); // custom formatter
       });

    A formatter is allowed to change a column's metadata, which will be reset after each rendered value. Also we can access the columns after they are defined as follows:

    
 TextTable.LayoutBuilder layout = TextTable.withColumns("Name", "Age", "Bio");
 DecimalFormat df = new DecimalFormat("#,###");
 layout.getAllColumns().each {c -> { // for all columns
   c.formatter = value -> {
       if (value instanceof Number) {
           c.alignment = 1; // right-align
           return df.format(((Number) value).longValue());
       }
       return String.valueOf(value).trim(); // will be left-aligned as default
   }
   c.defaultValue = new AtomicInteger::incrementAndGet;
 }}

    There is no synchronization in any of the classes, but both the columns and table are practically immutable once defined (unless the formatters change the column fields). This means that both tables and layouts can be shared between threads. The builders on the other side are stateful and they are best confined to a single thread.

    • Nested Class Summary

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      static class  TextTable.Box
      Preset styles, specifying the characters used to draw the lines and corners of a table.
      static class  TextTable.Column
      Defines the formatting attributes for a single column of a table.
      static class  TextTable.DataBuilder
      This builder can be used to build a dataset, that can be used together with the specified layout (a set of columns) to create a table.
      static class  TextTable.LayoutBuilder
      Provides a nice and compact DSL to build a set of columns for a table.
      static interface  TextTable.Style
      Specifies the characters used to draw the lines and corners of a table.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      static String eol
      End-of-line character used to separate the lines of the table.
      static String indent
      Pattern used to indent the table if not starting from column zero.
      static String padding
      Pattern used pad the table values when different from the column width.
      boolean pendingAutoformat
      If set to true, before calling format(int, Appendable) all column widths will be adjusted to fit the data, then this field will be reset to false.
      static TextTable.Style style
      Determines the characters used to draw the lines and corners of a table Defaults to ASCII graphics.

    • Field Detail

      • style

        public static volatile TextTable.Style style
        Determines the characters used to draw the lines and corners of a table Defaults to ASCII graphics.
        See Also:
        presetBox(Style), TextTable.Box

      • eol

        public static volatile String eol
        End-of-line character used to separate the lines of the table. Defaults to the OS-specific EOL character.
        See Also:
        presetBox(Style), System.lineSeparator()

      • padding

        public static volatile String padding
        Pattern used pad the table values when different from the column width. Could be longer than one character, in which case they will be repeated to fill the desired gap (useful for subtle counting patterns). Defaults to space character "\\u0020".
        See Also:
        presetBox(Style)

      • indent

        public static volatile String indent
        Pattern used to indent the table if not starting from column zero. Could be longer than one character, in which case they will be repeated to fill the desired gap (useful for subtle counting patterns). Defaults to space character "\\u0020".
        See Also:
        presetBox(Style)

      • pendingAutoformat

        public boolean pendingAutoformat
        If set to true, before calling format(int, Appendable) all column widths will be adjusted to fit the data, then this field will be reset to false.

    • Constructor Detail

      • TextTable

        public TextTable(@NotNull
                 @NotNull List<TextTable.Column> columns,
                 @NotNull
                 @NotNull List<List<?>> data)

        Constructor to create a table object given prepared columns and data. Typically one would use the builder API as follows:

        
 TextTable table = TextTable.withColumns(
                   "key"   , "value"
 ).withData().rows(
    new String[] { "abc"   ,  123     },
    new String[] { "foobar", "bazqux" },
 ).buildTable();

 table.format(10, System.out);   // print to stdout with indentation 10 chars
 logger.info(table.format(0, new StringBuilder()));   // log to a logger
        Parameters:
        columns - list of columns describing the layout of the table
        data - collection of data rows

    • Method Detail

      • presetBox

        public static void presetBox(@NotNull
                             @NotNull TextTable.Style style)
        Sets all static parameters of TextTable, affecting the visual style. Typically used with one of the Box presets: 
        
 presetBox(Box.UNICODE_THIN); // will draw the table using nice thin box characters.
        Parameters:
        style - the box preset to use. The EOL, indent and padding are always reset to the defaults.

      • withColumns

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @NotNull
public static @NotNull TextTable.LayoutBuilder withColumns(@NotNull
                                                                                          String... columnNames)
        Starts a builder chain for defining a layout, which one can use to create a table.
        Parameters:
        columnNames - a list of column names, if no customizations are needed
        Returns:
        a builder to customize the table layout
        See Also:
        TextTable.LayoutBuilder.column(String, Consumer), TextTable.LayoutBuilder.withData()

      • format

        @NotNull
public <F extends Appendable> F format(int indent,
                                                @NotNull
                                                F out)
                                         throws IOException

        Render the table as text, based on the layout, per-column formatter, alignment and padding; and the indent parameter. If pendingAutoformat field is set to true, this method will also adjust the widths of the columns, so that the data will fit in the table.

        Type Parameters:
        F - captures the type of the out parameter, so we can return it.
        Parameters:
        indent - the number of characters to put to the left of the start of the table.
        out - the destination to which to append the text.
        Returns:
        the out parameter for chaining.
        Throws:
        IOException - passing through exceptions from Appendable.append(char)
        See Also:
        pendingAutoformat

      • pad

        protected static <T extends Appendable> T pad(@NotNull
                                              T out,
                                              int length,
                                              @NotNull
                                              @NotNull String pad)

        Adds length characters of padding to the out parameter. The padding is filled by repeating the pad pattern as needed, trimming the last occurrence to size.

        For ecample, pad(out, 8, "abc") will result in "abcabcab" (8 characters) appened to the out parameter.

        Type Parameters:
        T - captures the type of the out parameter, so we can return it.
        Parameters:
        out - where to put the padding.
        length - how many characters to pad.
        pad - what pattern to use for padding.
        Returns:
        the out parameter for chaining.
